qas.question: What involves encoding information using fewer bits than the original representation?
What can be either lossy or lossless?
What reduces bits by identifying and eliminating statistical redundancy?
What is the process called of reducing the size of a data file?
What is the process called of encoding at the source of the data before it's processed?
What involves encoding information using fewer bits than the channel coding?
What can not be lossy or lossless?
What reduces bits by identifying and eliminating source coding?
What is the process called of reducing the size of a lossless?

context: In signal processing, <a0_0><b5_0>data compression<b5_0/><a0_0/>, source coding, or bit-rate reduction involves encoding information using fewer bits than the original representation. <a1_0><b6_0>Compression<b6_0/><a1_0/> can be either lossy or lossless. <a2_0><b7_0>Lossless compression<b7_0/><a2_0/> reduces bits by identifying and eliminating statistical redundancy. No information is lost in lossless compression. Lossy compression reduces bits by identifying unnecessary information and removing it. The process of reducing the size of a data file is referred to as <a3_0><b8_0>data compression<b8_0/><a3_0/>. In the context of data transmission, it is called <a4_0>source coding<a4_0/> (encoding done at the source of the data before it is stored or transmitted) in opposition to channel coding.
